title: Relates to enforcement of wage payment laws
summary: Relates to enforcement of wage payment laws; provides enhanced enforcement and penalty provision; permits private rights of action; defines independent contractor and permits action for improper classification of employees.

       Introduced  by M. of A. ORTIZ -- read once and referred to the Committee
         on Labor

       AN ACT to amend the labor law, in relation to the payment of wages

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section  1.  Subdivisions  2  and  3  of section 190 of the labor law,
    2  subdivision 2 as added by chapter 548 of the laws of 1966  and  subdivi-
    3  sion  3  as  amended by chapter 281 of the laws of 2002, are amended and
    4  two new subdivisions 10 and 11 are added to read as follows:
    5    2. "Employee" means [any person employed for hire by  an  employer  in
    6  any  employment]  A  NATURAL  PERSON WHO IS EMPLOYED IN THIS STATE BY AN
    7  EMPLOYER, INCLUDING AN INDIVIDUAL WHO IS IN RECEIPT OF OR IS ENTITLED TO
    8  ANY COMPENSATION FOR LABOR PERFORMED FOR  ANY  EMPLOYER.  EMPLOYEE  ALSO
    9  INCLUDES  A COMMISSION SALESPERSON WHO TAKES ORDERS OR PERFORMS SERVICES
   10  ON BEHALF OF A PRINCIPAL AND WHO IS PAID ON THE  BASIS  OF  COMMISSIONS,
   11  BUT  DOES  NOT  INCLUDE  PERSONS  WHO PURCHASE FOR THEIR OWN ACCOUNT FOR
   12  RESALE.
   13    3. "Employer" [includes any  person,  corporation,  limited  liability
   14  company,  or  association  employing  any  individual in any occupation,
   15  industry, trade, business or service] MEANS A  PERSON,  FIRM  OR  CORPO-
   16  RATION,  AGENT,  MANAGER,  REPRESENTATIVE,  CONTRACTOR, SUBCONTRACTOR OR
   17  PRINCIPAL, OR OTHER PERSON ACTING DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY IN THE INTEREST
   18  OF AN EMPLOYER TO SUFFER OR PERMIT ANOTHER PERSON  TO  WORK;  WHETHER  A
   19  PERSON  IS  AN INDEPENDENT CONTRACTOR OR AN EMPLOYEE SHALL BE DETERMINED
   20  ACCORDING TO THE STANDARDS OF THE FEDERAL FAIR LABOR STANDARDS  ACT,  29
   21  U.S.C.  201  TO 219, BUT THE BURDEN OF PROOF SHALL BE UPON THE PARTY FOR
   22  WHOM THE WORK IS PERFORMED TO  SHOW  INDEPENDENT  CONTRACTOR  STATUS  BY
   23  CLEAR  AND CONVINCING EVIDENCE.  The term "employer" shall not include a
   24  governmental agency.
   25    10. "INDEPENDENT CONTRACTOR" MEANS A PERSON WHO:

        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.
                                                                  LBD03970-01-1

       A. 1073                             2

    1    (A) PERFORMS SERVICES FREE FROM DIRECTION AND CONTROL OVER  THE  MEANS
    2  AND  MANNER  OF PROVIDING THE SERVICES, SUBJECT ONLY TO THE RIGHT OF THE
    3  PERSON OR ENTITY FOR WHOM SERVICES ARE PROVIDED TO SPECIFY  THE  DESIRED
    4  RESULT;
    5    (B)  FURNISHES  THE  TOOLS  AND  EQUIPMENT  NECESSARY  TO  PROVIDE THE
    6  SERVICE;
    7    (C) OPERATES A BUSINESS THAT IS CONSIDERED INSEPARABLE FROM THE  INDI-
    8  VIDUAL FOR PURPOSES OF TAXES, PROFITS, AND LIABILITIES:
    9    (I) IN WHICH THE INDIVIDUAL:
   10    (A) OWNS ALL OF THE ASSETS AND PROFITS OF THE BUSINESS; AND
   11    (B)  HAS  SOLE, UNLIMITED, PERSONAL LIABILITY FOR ALL OF THE DEBTS AND
   12  LIABILITIES OF THE BUSINESS, UNLESS  THE  BUSINESS  IS  ORGANIZED  AS  A
   13  SINGLE-OWNED CORPORATE ENTITY, TO WHICH SOLE, UNLIMITED PERSONAL LIABIL-
   14  ITY DOES NOT APPLY; AND
   15    (II) FOR WHICH:
   16    (A)  THE INDIVIDUAL DOES NOT PAY TAXES FOR THE BUSINESS SEPARATELY BUT
   17  REPORTS BUSINESS INCOME AND LOSSES  ON  THE  INDIVIDUAL'S  PERSONAL  TAX
   18  RETURN; AND
   19    (B)  IF  THE BUSINESS IS ORGANIZED AS A CORPORATE ENTITY AND THE INDI-
   20  VIDUAL OTHERWISE QUALIFIES AS AN EXEMPT PERSON UNDER THIS  ARTICLE,  THE
   21  INDIVIDUAL  FILES  A  SEPARATE  FEDERAL INFORMATIONAL TAX RETURN FOR THE
   22  ENTITY AS REQUIRED BY LAW;
   23    (D) EXERCISES COMPLETE CONTROL OVER THE MANAGEMENT AND  OPERATIONS  OF
   24  THE BUSINESS; AND
   25    (E)  EXERCISES  THE  RIGHT  AND  OPPORTUNITY  ON A CONTINUING BASIS TO
   26  PERFORM THE SERVICES OF THE BUSINESS FOR MULTIPLE ENTITIES AT THE  INDI-
   27  VIDUAL'S SOLE CHOICE AND DISCRETION.
   28    11.  "LIQUIDATED  DAMAGES" MEANS THE SUM OF FIVE PERCENT MULTIPLIED BY
   29  THE AMOUNT OF ANY WAGES THAT WERE NOT PAID OR OF ANY AUTHORIZED EXPENSES
   30  THAT WERE NOT REIMBURSED ON A REGULAR PAYDAY OR ON ANOTHER  DAY,  MULTI-
   31  PLIED  BY  THE  TOTAL NUMBER OF DAYS, EXCLUDING SUNDAYS, LEGAL HOLIDAYS,
   32  AND THE FIRST SEVEN DAYS AFTER THE REGULAR PAYDAY ON  WHICH  WAGES  WERE
   33  NOT  PAID  OR  EXPENSES WERE NOT REIMBURSED. HOWEVER, SUCH SUM SHALL NOT
   34  EXCEED TWICE THE AMOUNT OF THE UNPAID WAGES  AND  SHALL  NOT  ACCUMULATE
   35  WHEN AN EMPLOYER IS SUBJECT TO A PETITION FILED IN BANKRUPTCY.
   36    S 2. The labor law is amended by adding a new section 191-d to read as
   37  follows:
   38    S  191-D.  PRIVATE  RIGHT  OF  ACTION BY MISCLASSIFIED EMPLOYEES.   1.
   39  NOTWITHSTANDING ANY REMEDY AVAILABLE UNDER THIS ARTICLE,  AN  INDIVIDUAL
   40  WHO  HAS  NOT  BEEN PROPERLY CLASSIFIED AS AN EMPLOYEE MAY BRING A CIVIL
   41  ACTION FOR DAMAGES AGAINST THE EMPLOYER FOR ANY VIOLATION OF THIS  ARTI-
   42  CLE.
   43    2.  AN  ACTION  FILED  UNDER  THIS SECTION SHALL BE FILED WITHIN THREE
   44  YEARS AFTER THE DATE THE CAUSE OF ACTION ACCRUES.
   45    3. IF THE COURT DETERMINES THAT AN INDIVIDUAL OR CLASS OF  INDIVIDUALS
   46  IS  ENTITLED  TO  JUDGMENT  IN  AN  ACTION  AGAINST AN EMPLOYER FILED IN
   47  ACCORDANCE WITH THIS SECTION, THE COURT MAY AWARD EACH INDIVIDUAL:
   48    (A) ANY DAMAGES TO WHICH THE INDIVIDUAL MAY  BE  ENTITLED  UNDER  THIS
   49  ARTICLE;
   50    (B)  AN  ADDITIONAL  AMOUNT  UP  TO THREE TIMES THE AMOUNT OF ANY SUCH
   51  DAMAGES, IF THE EMPLOYER KNOWINGLY FAILED TO PROPERLY CLASSIFY THE INDI-
   52  VIDUAL;
   53    (C) REASONABLE COUNSEL FEES AND OTHER COSTS OF THE ACTION; AND
   54    (D) ANY OTHER APPROPRIATE RELIEF.
   55    S 3. The labor law is amended by adding a new section 191-e to read as
   56  follows:

       A. 1073                             3

    1    S 191-E. PRIVATE ATTORNEYS GENERAL PROVISION FOR ENFORCEMENT.  1.  (A)
    2  NOTWITHSTANDING  ANY OTHER PROVISION OF LAW, ANY PROVISION OF THIS ARTI-
    3  CLE THAT PROVIDES FOR A CIVIL PENALTY TO BE ASSESSED  AND  COLLECTED  BY
    4  THE  COMMISSIONER  MAY,  AS AN ALTERNATIVE, BE RECOVERED THROUGH A CIVIL
    5  ACTION  BROUGHT BY AN AGGRIEVED EMPLOYEE ON BEHALF OF HIMSELF OR HERSELF
    6  AND OTHER CURRENT OR FORMER EMPLOYEES.
    7    (B) NO ACTION MAY BE  BROUGHT  UNDER  THIS  SECTION  BY  AN  AGGRIEVED
    8  EMPLOYEE  IF  THE  COMMISSIONER  ON THE SAME FACTS AND THEORIES, CITES A
    9  PERSON WITHIN THE TIMEFRAMES SET FORTH IN THIS ARTICLE FOR  A  VIOLATION
   10  OF THE SAME SECTION OR SECTIONS OF LAW UNDER WHICH THE AGGRIEVED EMPLOY-
   11  EE  IS  ATTEMPTING  TO  RECOVER  A CIVIL PENALTY ON BEHALF OF HIMSELF OR
   12  HERSELF OR OTHERS.
   13    (C) CIVIL PENALTIES RECOVERED BY AGGRIEVED EMPLOYEES SHALL BE DISTRIB-
   14  UTED AS FOLLOWS: SEVENTY-FIVE PERCENT TO THE COMMISSION FOR  ENFORCEMENT
   15  OF  LABOR  LAWS  AND  EDUCATION  OF  EMPLOYERS AND EMPLOYEES ABOUT THEIR
   16  RIGHTS AND RESPONSIBILITIES  UNDER  THIS  ARTICLE,  TO  BE  CONTINUOUSLY
   17  APPROPRIATED  TO  SUPPLEMENT  AND NOT SUPPLANT THE FUNDING TO THE AGENCY
   18  FOR THOSE PURPOSES; AND TWENTY-FIVE PERCENT TO THE AGGRIEVED EMPLOYEES.
   19    (D) COURTS SHALL REVIEW AND APPROVE ANY PENALTIES SOUGHT AS PART OF  A
   20  PROPOSED SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT PURSUANT TO THIS SECTION.
   21    2. (A) A CIVIL ACTION BY AN AGGRIEVED EMPLOYEE SEEKING CIVIL PENALTIES
   22  PURSUANT  TO  THIS  SECTION  ALLEGING A VIOLATION OF ANY PROVISION SHALL
   23  COMMENCE ONLY AFTER THE FOLLOWING REQUIREMENTS HAVE BEEN MET:
   24    (I) THE AGGRIEVED EMPLOYEE OR REPRESENTATIVE SHALL GIVE WRITTEN NOTICE
   25  BY CERTIFIED MAIL TO THE DEPARTMENT AND THE  EMPLOYER  OF  THE  SPECIFIC
   26  PROVISIONS  OF THIS ARTICLE ALLEGED TO HAVE BEEN VIOLATED, INCLUDING THE
   27  FACTS AND THEORIES TO SUPPORT THE ALLEGED VIOLATION.
   28    (II) (A) THE DEPARTMENT SHALL NOTIFY THE EMPLOYER  AND  THE  AGGRIEVED
   29  EMPLOYEE  OR REPRESENTATIVE BY CERTIFIED MAIL THAT IT DOES NOT INTEND TO
   30  INVESTIGATE THE ALLEGED VIOLATION WITHIN THIRTY  CALENDAR  DAYS  OF  THE
   31  POSTMARK  DATE  OF  THE  NOTICE RECEIVED PURSUANT TO SUBPARAGRAPH (I) OF
   32  THIS PARAGRAPH. UPON RECEIPT OF THAT NOTICE OR IF NO NOTICE IS  PROVIDED
   33  WITHIN  THIRTY-THREE  CALENDAR  DAYS  OF THE POSTMARK DATE OF THE NOTICE
   34  GIVEN PURSUANT TO SUCH SUBPARAGRAPH  (I),  THE  AGGRIEVED  EMPLOYEE  MAY
   35  COMMENCE A CIVIL ACTION.
   36    (B) IF THE DEPARTMENT INTENDS TO INVESTIGATE THE ALLEGED VIOLATION, IT
   37  SHALL  NOTIFY  THE EMPLOYER AND THE AGGRIEVED EMPLOYEE OR REPRESENTATIVE
   38  BY CERTIFIED MAIL OF ITS DECISION WITHIN THIRTY-THREE CALENDAR  DAYS  OF
   39  THE POSTMARK DATE OF THE NOTICE RECEIVED PURSUANT TO SUBPARAGRAPH (I) OF
   40  THIS  PARAGRAPH.  WITHIN  ONE HUNDRED TWENTY CALENDAR DAYS OF THAT DECI-
   41  SION, THE AGENCY MAY INVESTIGATE THE ALLEGED  VIOLATION  AND  ISSUE  ANY
   42  APPROPRIATE  CITATION. IF THE AGENCY DETERMINES THAT NO CITATION WILL BE
   43  ISSUED, IT SHALL NOTIFY THE EMPLOYER  AND  AGGRIEVED  EMPLOYEE  OF  THAT
   44  DECISION  WITHIN  FIVE  BUSINESS  DAYS  THEREOF  BY CERTIFIED MAIL. UPON
   45  RECEIPT OF THAT NOTICE OR IF NO CITATION IS ISSUED BY THE AGENCY  WITHIN
   46  THE  ONE  HUNDRED FIFTY-EIGHT-DAY PERIOD PRESCRIBED BY THIS PARAGRAPH OR
   47  IF THE AGENCY FAILS TO PROVIDE TIMELY OR ANY NOTIFICATION, THE AGGRIEVED
   48  EMPLOYEE MAY COMMENCE A CIVIL ACTION.
   49    (C) NOTWITHSTANDING ANY OTHER PROVISION OF LAW, A PLAINTIFF MAY  AS  A
   50  MATTER  OF  RIGHT  AMEND  AN EXISTING COMPLAINT TO ADD A CAUSE OF ACTION
   51  ARISING UNDER THIS SECTION AT ANY TIME WITHIN SIXTY  DAYS  OF  THE  TIME
   52  PERIODS SPECIFIED IN THIS SECTION.
   53    S  4. Section 195 of the labor law is amended by adding a new subdivi-
   54  sion 7 to read as follows:
   55    7. ON EACH REGULAR PAYDAY, SEND TO EACH EMPLOYEE BY MAIL OR PROVIDE AT
   56  THE EMPLOYEE'S NORMAL PLACE OF EMPLOYMENT DURING NORMAL EMPLOYMENT HOURS

       A. 1073                             4

    1  A STATEMENT SHOWING THE HOURS THE EMPLOYEE WORKED, THE WAGES  EARNED  BY
    2  THE EMPLOYEE, AND DEDUCTIONS MADE FOR THE EMPLOYEE.
    3    S  5. Subdivision 2 of section 196 of the labor law, as added by chap-
    4  ter 548 of the laws of 1966, is amended to read as follows:
    5    2. THE COMMISSIONER MAY  HOLD  HEARINGS  AND  INVESTIGATE  CHARGES  OF
    6  VIOLATIONS OF THIS ARTICLE.
    7    3. THE COMMISSIONER MAY, CONSISTENT WITH DUE PROCESS OF LAW, ENTER ANY
    8  PLACE OF EMPLOYMENT TO INSPECT RECORDS CONCERNING WAGES AND PAYROLLS, TO
    9  QUESTION  THE  EMPLOYER  AND  EMPLOYEES,  AND TO INVESTIGATE SUCH FACTS,
   10  CONDITIONS OR MATTERS AS ARE DEEMED APPROPRIATE IN  DETERMINING  WHETHER
   11  ANY PERSON HAS VIOLATED THE PROVISIONS OF THIS ARTICLE.  THE NAME OF ANY
   12  EMPLOYEE  IDENTIFIED  IN  A  COMPLAINT  TO  THE DEPARTMENT SHALL BE KEPT
   13  CONFIDENTIAL AS LONG AS POSSIBLE. WHERE THE DEPARTMENT  DETERMINES  THAT
   14  AN EMPLOYEE'S NAME MUST BE DISCLOSED IN ORDER TO INVESTIGATE A COMPLAINT
   15  FURTHER, IT MAY DO SO ONLY WITH THE EMPLOYEE'S CONSENT.
   16    4. Nothing in this section shall be construed as requiring the commis-
   17  sioner in every instance to investigate and attempt to adjust controver-
   18  sies,  or  to  take assignments of wage claims, or to institute criminal
   19  prosecutions for any violation under  this  article,  but  he  shall  be
   20  deemed vested with discretion in such matters.
   21    S 6. The labor law is amended by adding a new section 196-b to read as
   22  follows:
   23    S  196-B.  RETALIATION  AGAINST  EMPLOYEES  PROHIBITED.  NO  PERSON OR
   24  EMPLOYER SHALL DISCHARGE OR IN ANY OTHER MANNER DISCRIMINATE OR  RETALI-
   25  ATE  AGAINST  AN EMPLOYEE OR OTHER PERSON FOR EXERCISING ANY RIGHT UNDER
   26  THIS ARTICLE OR ANY REGULATION IMPLEMENTING ITS PROVISIONS,  OR  AGAINST
   27  ANY  PERSON  FOR  PROVIDING  ASSISTANCE  TO  ANY EMPLOYEE OR INFORMATION
   28  REGARDING THE SAME, OR FOR TESTIFYING OR  PLANNING  TO  TESTIFY  IN  ANY
   29  INVESTIGATION  OR  PROCEEDING  REGARDING THE SAME. TAKING ADVERSE ACTION
   30  AGAINST A PERSON WITHIN NINETY DAYS OF A PERSON'S ENGAGING IN THE  FORE-
   31  GOING  ACTIVITIES SHALL RAISE A PRESUMPTION THAT SUCH ACTION WAS RETALI-
   32  ATION, WHICH MAY BE REBUTTED BY CLEAN AND CONVINCING EVIDENCE THAT  SUCH
   33  ACTION  WAS TAKEN FOR OTHER PERMISSIBLE REASONS. ANY EMPLOYEE MAY FILE A
   34  COMPLAINT WITH THE COMMISSIONER  ALLEGING  DISCHARGE  OR  DISCRIMINATION
   35  WITHIN  THIRTY  DAYS  AFTER  SUCH  VIOLATION OCCURS. UPON RECEIPT OF THE
   36  COMPLAINT, THE COMMISSIONER SHALL CAUSE AN INVESTIGATION TO BE  MADE  TO
   37  THE  EXTENT  DEEMED APPROPRIATE. IF THE COMMISSIONER DETERMINES FROM THE
   38  INVESTIGATION THAT THE PROVISIONS OF THIS ARTICLE  HAVE  BEEN  VIOLATED,
   39  THE COMMISSIONER SHALL BRING AN ACTION IN A COURT OF COMPETENT JURISDIC-
   40  TION  AGAINST SUCH PERSON. SUCH COURT SHALL ORDER ALL APPROPRIATE RELIEF
   41  INCLUDING REHIRING OR REINSTATEMENT OF THE EMPLOYEE TO THE FORMER  POSI-
   42  TION  WITH  BACK PAY. A CIVIL ACTION TO ENFORCE THIS ARTICLE MAY ALSO BE
   43  MAINTAINED IN ANY COURT OF COMPETENT JURISDICTION BY THE STATE OR BY ANY
   44  PARTY INURED BY A VIOLATION OF THIS ARTICLE. ANY EMPLOYER WHO RETALIATES
   45  AGAINST AN EMPLOYEE OR OTHER PERSON IN VIOLATION OF THIS  ARTICLE  SHALL
   46  BE REQUIRED TO PAY THE PERSON AN AMOUNT SET BY THE DEPARTMENT OR A COURT
   47  SUFFICIENT  TO  COMPENSATE THE EMPLOYEE AND DETER FUTURE VIOLATIONS, BUT
   48  NOT LESS THAN ONE HUNDRED DOLLARS  FOR  EACH  DAY  THAT  THE  VIOLATIONS
   49  CONTINUED, OR UNTIL LEGAL JUDGMENT IS FINAL.
   50    S  7.  Subdivision  1-a of section 198 of the labor law, as amended by
   51  chapter 372 of the laws of 2009, is amended to read as follows:
   52    1-a. On behalf of any employee paid less than the wage to which he  or
   53  she  is  entitled under the provisions of this article, the commissioner
   54  may bring any legal action necessary, including  administrative  action,
   55  to  collect  such claim and as part of such legal action, in addition to
   56  any other remedies and penalties otherwise available under this article,

       A. 1073                             5

    1  the commissioner may assess against the employer an additional amount as
    2  liquidated damages [equal to twenty-five percent of the total amount  of
    3  wages  found to be due] AS DEFINED IN SECTION ONE HUNDRED NINETY OF THIS
    4  ARTICLE,  unless  the  employer  proves a good faith basis for believing
    5  that its underpayment of wages was in compliance with the law.   In  any
    6  action  instituted in the courts upon a wage claim by an employee or the
    7  commissioner in which the employee prevails, the court shall allow  such
    8  employee  reasonable  attorney's  fees and, unless the employer proves a
    9  good faith basis to believe  that  its  underpayment  of  wages  was  in
   10  compliance  with  the  law,  an  additional amount as liquidated damages
   11  [equal to twenty-five percent of the total amount of the wages found  to
   12  be due] AS DEFINED IN SECTION ONE HUNDRED NINETY OF THIS ARTICLE.
   13    S  8.  Subdivision  1 of section 198-a of the labor law, as amended by
   14  chapter 241 of the laws of 2002, is amended to read as follows:
   15    1. Every employer who does not pay the wages of all of  his  employees
   16  in  accordance with the provisions of this chapter, and the officers and
   17  agents of any corporation  [who  knowingly  permit  the  corporation  to
   18  violate]  WHICH VIOLATES this chapter by failing to pay the wages of any
   19  of its employees in accordance with the  provisions  thereof,  shall  be
   20  guilty of a misdemeanor for the first offense and upon conviction there-
   21  for shall be fined not less than five hundred nor more than twenty thou-
   22  sand dollars or imprisoned for not more than one year, and, in the event
   23  that  any  second  or  subsequent offense occurs within six years of the
   24  date of conviction for a prior offense, shall be guilty of a felony  for
   25  the second or subsequent offense, and upon conviction therefor, shall be
   26  fined  not  less than five hundred nor more than twenty thousand dollars
   27  or imprisoned for not more than one year plus one day,  or  punished  by
   28  both  such  fine and imprisonment, for each such offense.  ADDITIONALLY,
   29  THE TEN LARGEST SHAREHOLDERS, AS DETERMINED BY THE FAIR VALUE  OF  THEIR
   30  BENEFICIAL  INTEREST  AS OF THE BEGINNING OF THE PERIOD DURING WHICH THE
   31  UNPAID SERVICES REFERRED TO IN THIS  ARTICLE  ARE  PERFORMED,  OF  EVERY
   32  CORPORATION  (OTHER  THAN AN INVESTMENT COMPANY REGISTERED AS SUCH UNDER
   33  AN ACT OF CONGRESS ENTITLED "INVESTMENT COMPANY ACT OF 1940"), NO SHARES
   34  OF WHICH ARE LISTED ON A NATIONAL SECURITIES EXCHANGE OR REGULARLY QUOT-
   35  ED IN AN OVER-THE-COUNTER MARKET BY ONE OR MORE MEMBERS OF A NATIONAL OR
   36  AN AFFILIATED SECURITIES ASSOCIATION, SHALL  JOINTLY  AND  SEVERALLY  BE
   37  PERSONALLY  LIABLE FOR ALL DEBTS, WAGES OR SALARIES DUE AND OWING TO ANY
   38  OF ITS EMPLOYEES FOR SERVICES PERFORMED BY THEM FOR SUCH CORPORATION.  A
   39  CIVIL  ACTION  MAY BE BROUGHT AGAINST A SHAREHOLDER LIABLE FOR WAGES DUE
   40  UNDER THIS CHAPTER INSTEAD OF  AND  IN  ADDITION  TO  THE  EMPLOYER.  An
   41  indictment of a person or corporation operating a steam surface railroad
   42  for  an  offense specified in this section may be found and tried in any
   43  county within the state in which such railroad ran at the time  of  such
   44  offense.
   45    S  9. Section 198-a of the labor law is amended by adding a new subdi-
   46  vision 4 to read as follows:
   47    4. ANY WEEK WHERE AN INDIVIDUAL EMPLOYEE  WAS  NOT  PAID  THE  LEGALLY
   48  REQUIRED  WAGES UNDER THIS ARTICLE, STATE TAXES WERE NOT WITHHELD, OR IN
   49  THE CASE OF RETALIATION AGAINST AN EMPLOYEE, EVERY  WEEK  AFTER  RETALI-
   50  ATION  HAS OCCURRED UNTIL COMPENSATION IS FINALLY MADE, SHALL CONSTITUTE
   51  A SEPARATE VIOLATION OF THE PROVISIONS OF THIS ARTICLE.
   52    S 10. This act shall take effect immediately.
actClause: AN ACT to amend the labor law, in relation to the payment of wages
